 guidelines on what is healthy to eat?



These guidelines will be used to drive policies such as where your tax dollars get spent, and to determine the advice given to those who approach Doctors, Dietitians and other other health care professionals when looking for ways to get healthier.



The guidelines were NOT issued by any health department but rather by the US Department of AGRICULTURE. question: Sourdough bread may be better than whole wheat
answers: I absolutely love sourdough bread. I don't eat it though. The carb counts on sourdough bread are more than double the carbs per slice of any other bread. I don't eat much bread at all but when I do it's a thin slice of light bread at 8 carbs per slice. Most sourdough bread I've seen around here is 25 carbs per slice. One slice of bread would my whole meals worth of carbs.

For me.....sourdough bread is like taking a piece of white bread and pouring a Coke on it.

I go through the roof.....Of course I love the stuff...just can't hardly eat it.

Certainly everyone is different, but what I found interesting is the finding that the oft-recommended "whole wheat" bread had greater impact and over a longer period of time.  It's not always sufficient to give a passing grade to something that doesn't spike you very much at two hours.
There are sourdough breads out there at 15 g a slice. Also Russian Rye and Pumpernickel breads at 15 g a slice.

Like pizza?  
  I agree with you to that extent--the 2 hour reading isn't the end all and be all of careful glucose monitor regimens.

I don't need a study to tell me which bread is better for my glucose levels. All I have to do is eat some and test...and by this time I know that any kind of bread is out for me. I have had french bread, sourdough bread, soy bread, flaxseed bread, even the low carb bread that some bakeries sell. I can't tolerate any of them. But there is one light whole wheat bread that my supermarket sells..9 carbs per slice, that I can tolerate the best, but not enough that I want to eat it too often. Maybe half a slice...I can try that. Anyway, my point being, and I know you know this already, is doesn't matter what any study says. Listen to your meter.

Chiming in.  I make sourdough at home and use whole wheat flour. I am back to prediabetic after being diagnosed with type II. Lost some weight, and eliminated most carbs. The starter I use has been acclimated to whole wheat and I love it. Since I eat very few carbs, the sourdough doesn't seem to affect me as much as rice, white bread, potatoes, etc. I don't get groggy, and my extremities don't swell. But I only eat a couple slices at a time and haven't measure blood sugar diligently. But I do recommend it as long as you make it at home if you crave carbs like I do. It took me five years to lose the sugar craving, and I'm really just starting to work on the carb craving. It seems more difficult since there are always carbs around in one form or another.



PS- you can get 50 lbs of flour for around $15, and sourdough is easy to make, just takes some time.

Yes I know everyone is different, but this was the single worst mistake I ever made diet-wise on my diabetes journey, hands down.

There has been an enormous amount of progress with implanted beta cells protected by immunosuppressant drugs. One approach is encapsulating the cells in a protective layer and then giving localized immunosuppressant drugs right at the site of the transplant. Beta cells also crave oxygen, so there has been engineering work to create chemical reactions that can produce oxygen for 30 days while the beta cells attach to the vascular system. This approach means that you experience no side effects from the drugs (the doses are minuscule compared to taking a full body dose). Other approaches are using stem cells to culture beta cells that don't need immunosuppressants and encapsulating those to save them from the autoimmune response. Both of these approaches are working in animal models and headings towards human trials.

question: Sourdough bread may be better than whole wheat
answers: I absolutely love sourdough bread. I don't eat it though. The carb counts on sourdough bread are more than double the carbs per slice of any other bread. I don't eat much bread at all but when I do it's a thin slice of light bread at 8 carbs per slice. Most sourdough bread I've seen around here is 25 carbs per slice. One slice of bread would my whole meals worth of carbs.

For me.....sourdough bread is like taking a piece of white bread and pouring a Coke on it.

I go through the roof.....Of course I love the stuff...just can't hardly eat it.

Certainly everyone is different, but what I found interesting is the finding that the oft-recommended "whole wheat" bread had greater impact and over a longer period of time.  It's not always sufficient to give a passing grade to something that doesn't spike you very much at two hours.

Katerina, clinical trials take 8 years on average to complete. So two years to complete a phase 1 trial is completely normal. The FDA does not let you test the drug on two or three people and then move on. She needs to prove that this treatment has a positive effect in limited doses over hundreds or thousands of individuals that fit a diverse set of requirements. The study needs to be double-blind and randomized. This takes time and is expensive. 



For an example of why this is expensive, you need only look at her lab equipment. To test if the treatment is having a positive effect on the "bad" t-cells, she built a machine that can sort 1 type of t-cell out of a million other blood cells. This machine costs millions of dollars and a team of engineers to build. And that's merely one small component of completing this project.



To put this in perspective, if she was creating a new drug, it would cost at least $1,000,000,000 - that's one billion dollars - to get to the start of a phase 1 clinical trial. The process to bring a treatment market is expensive and time-consuming no matter how you look at it. 



So I would not look at the minor money involved here (well under $50,000,000) or the short time (less than 24 months to complete a phase 1 trial) and see anything but positive signs. As AlbertE said, most trials never even get to a phase II so this is actually good news all around.

She needs to prove that this treatment has a positive effect in limited doses over hundreds or thousands of individuals that fit a diverse set of requirements. The study needs to be double-blind and randomized. This takes time and is expensive. 



For an example of why this is expensive, you need only look at her lab equipment. To test if the treatment is having a positive effect on the "bad" t-cells, she built a machine that can sort 1 type of t-cell out of a million other blood cells. This machine costs millions of dollars and a team of engineers to build. And that's merely one small component of completing this project.



To put this in perspective, if she was creating a new drug, it would cost at least $1,000,000,000 - that's one billion dollars - to get to the start of a phase 1 clinical trial. The process to bring a treatment market is expensive and time-consuming no matter how you look at it. 



So I would not look at the minor money involved here (well under $50,000,000) or the short time (less than 24 months to complete a phase 1 trial) and see anything but positive signs. As AlbertE said, most trials never even get to a phase II so this is actually good news all around.

question: Sourdough bread may be better than whole wheat
answers: I absolutely love sourdough bread. I don't eat it though. The carb counts on sourdough bread are more than double the carbs per slice of any other bread. There has been an enormous amount of progress with implanted beta cells protected by immunosuppressant drugs. One approach is encapsulating the cells in a protective layer and then giving localized immunosuppressant drugs right at the site of the transplant. Beta cells also crave oxygen, so there has been engineering work to create chemical reactions that can produce oxygen for 30 days while the beta cells attach to the vascular system. This approach means that you experience no side effects from the drugs (the doses are minuscule compared to taking a full body dose). Other approaches are using stem cells to culture beta cells that don't need immunosuppressants and encapsulating those to save them from the autoimmune response. Both of these approaches are working in animal models and headings towards human trials.

There has been an enormous amount of progress with implanted beta cells protected by immunosuppressant drugs. One approach is encapsulating the cells in a protective layer and then giving localized immunosuppressant drugs right at the site of the transplant. Beta cells also crave oxygen, so there has been engineering work to create chemical reactions that can produce oxygen for 30 days while the beta cells attach to the vascular system. This approach means that you experience no side effects from the drugs (the doses are minuscule compared to taking a full body dose). Other approaches are using stem cells to culture beta cells that don't need immunosuppressants and encapsulating those to save them from the autoimmune response. Both of these approaches are working in animal models and headings towards human trials.

question: Sourdough bread may be better than whole wheat
answers: I absolutely love sourdough bread. I don't eat it though. The carb counts on sourdough bread are more than double the carbs per slice of any other bread. I don't eat much bread at all but when I do it's a thin slice of light bread at 8 carbs per slice. Most sourdough bread I've seen around here is 25 carbs per slice. One slice of bread would my whole meals worth of carbs.

For me.....sourdough bread is like taking a piece of white bread and pouring a Coke on it.

I go through the roof.....Of course I love the stuff...just can't hardly eat it.

Certainly everyone is different, but what I found interesting is the finding that the oft-recommended "whole wheat" bread had greater impact and over a longer period of time.  It's not always sufficient to give a passing grade to something that doesn't spike you very much at two hours.

There has been an enormous amount of progress with implanted beta cells protected by immunosuppressant drugs. One approach is encapsulating the cells in a protective layer and then giving localized immunosuppressant drugs right at the site of the transplant. Beta cells also crave oxygen, so there has been engineering work to create chemical reactions that can produce oxygen for 30 days while the beta cells attach to the vascular system. Katerina, clinical trials take 8 years on average to complete. So two years to complete a phase 1 trial is completely normal. The FDA does not let you test the drug on two or three people and then move on. She needs to prove that this treatment has a positive effect in limited doses over hundreds or thousands of individuals that fit a diverse set of requirements. The study needs to be double-blind and randomized. This takes time and is expensive. 



For an example of why this is expensive, you need only look at her lab equipment. To test if the treatment is having a positive effect on the "bad" t-cells, she built a machine that can sort 1 type of t-cell out of a million other blood cells. This machine costs millions of dollars and a team of engineers to build. And that's merely one small component of completing this project.



To put this in perspective, if she was creating a new drug, it would cost at least $1,000,000,000 - that's one billion dollars - to get to the start of a phase 1 clinical trial. The process to bring a treatment market is expensive and time-consuming no matter how you look at it. 



So I would not look at the minor money involved here (well under $50,000,000) or the short time (less than 24 months to complete a phase 1 trial) and see anything but positive signs. As AlbertE said, most trials never even get to a phase II so this is actually good news all around.

There has been an enormous amount of progress with implanted beta cells protected by immunosuppressant drugs. One approach is encapsulating the cells in a protective layer and then giving localized immunosuppressant drugs right at the site of the transplant. Beta cells also crave oxygen, so there has been engineering work to create chemical reactions that can produce oxygen for 30 days while the beta cells attach to the vascular system. This approach means that you experience no side effects from the drugs (the doses are minuscule compared to taking a full body dose). Other approaches are using stem cells to culture beta cells that don't need immunosuppressants and encapsulating those to save them from the autoimmune response. Both of these approaches are working in animal models and headings towards human trials.

question: Sourdough bread may be better than whole wheat
answers: I absolutely love sourdough bread. I don't eat it though. The carb counts on sourdough bread are more than double the carbs per slice of any other bread. There has been an enormous amount of progress with implanted beta cells protected by immunosuppressant drugs. One approach is encapsulating the cells in a protective layer and then giving localized immunosuppressant drugs right at the site of the transplant. Beta cells also crave oxygen, so there has been engineering work to create chemical reactions that can produce oxygen for 30 days while the beta cells attach to the vascular system. This approach means that you experience no side effects from the drugs (the doses are minuscule compared to taking a full body dose). Other approaches are using stem cells to culture beta cells that don't need immunosuppressants and encapsulating those to save them from the autoimmune response. Both of these approaches are working in animal models and headings towards human trials.

question: Sourdough bread may be better than whole wheat
answers: I absolutely love sourdough bread. I don't eat it though. The carb counts on sourdough bread are more than double the carbs per slice of any other bread. There has been an enormous amount of progress with implanted beta cells protected by immunosuppressant drugs. One approach is encapsulating the cells in a protective layer and then giving localized immunosuppressant drugs right at the site of the transplant. Beta cells also crave oxygen, so there has been engineering work to create chemical reactions that can produce oxygen for 30 days while the beta cells attach to the vascular system. question: Sourdough bread may be better than whole wheat
answers: I absolutely love sourdough bread. I don't eat it though. The carb counts on sourdough bread are more than double the carbs per slice of any other bread. I don't eat much bread at all but when I do it's a thin slice of light bread at 8 carbs per slice. Most sourdough bread I've seen around here is 25 carbs per slice. One slice of bread would my whole meals worth of carbs.

For me.....sourdough bread is like taking a piece of white bread and pouring a Coke on it.

I go through the roof.....Of course I love the stuff...just can't hardly eat it.

There has been an enormous amount of progress with implanted beta cells protected by immunosuppressant drugs. One approach is encapsulating the cells in a protective layer and then giving localized immunosuppressant drugs right at the site of the transplant. Beta cells also crave oxygen, so there has been engineering work to create chemical reactions that can produce oxygen for 30 days while the beta cells attach to the vascular system. This approach means that you experience no side effects from the drugs (the doses are minuscule compared to taking a full body dose). Other approaches are using stem cells to culture beta cells that don't need immunosuppressants and encapsulating those to save them from the autoimmune response. Both of these approaches are working in animal models and headings towards human trials.

I found this excerpt from Life Extension Magazine, March 2016:



Dr. Robert Temple, deputy director at the FDA:  

Their hope is that a wide variety of age-related problems, loss of muscle tone, dizziness, falls, dementia, loss of eyesight, all of those things (sic). That would be something never done before. If you really are doing something to alter aging, the population of interest is everybody. It surely would be revolutionary if they can bring it off.

https://trialsjournal.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s13063-017-1932-5

That's as far as I'm going to look into it. If anyone wants to add anything, please do.
		


Click to expand...





All of those things have been connected to too much glucose processing and too much glucose in the system. Metformin has a clear role in reducing the overall amount of glucose by suppressing liver glucose production. Did they even bother to control for that? I doubt it but sorry, I don't feel like reading more vaporware research. Once they start advocating for some drug, it seems they'll stop at nothing to convince us it's manna from heaven.



If Metformin only has those effects because it lowers overall glucose, then the REAL question is what is the best way to achieve lower overall glucose. Personally, I don't think taking Metformin or any other drug should be the first-line approach when there are much healthier and less intrusive ways to the same end in most cases. You know, the one they're still fighting tooth and nail in complete defiance of reality and science?



Side-by-side if they compared taking Met to reducing carbs in diet, I have no doubt the latter would WIN hands-down by a long shot on all points. And without the well-known motor and cognitive side-effects, even if the RATE of same is in dispute. If it weren't for the fact that the only way to reduce carbs in diet is to replace them with fats (their "devil"), they probably would have recognized this long ago. It was common knowledge and used in hospitals in 1915 - before the new "devil" was invented and before pharma had so much at stake.



I call "blood sugar" (i.e., BS).

Well, there are no results yet in the link. And we are already 3 days into January?  
What is taking them so long?

question: Sourdough bread may be better than whole wheat
answers: I absolutely love sourdough bread. I don't eat it though. The carb counts on sourdough bread are more than double the carbs per slice of any other bread. I don't eat much bread at all but when I do it's a thin slice of light bread at 8 carbs per slice. Most sourdough bread I've seen around here is 25 carbs per slice. One slice of bread would my whole meals worth of carbs.

For me.....sourdough bread is like taking a piece of white bread and pouring a Coke on it.

I go through the roof.....Of course I love the stuff...just can't hardly eat it.

Certainly everyone is different, but what I found interesting is the finding that the oft-recommended "whole wheat" bread had greater impact and over a longer period of time.  It's not always sufficient to give a passing grade to something that doesn't spike you very much at two hours.
There are sourdough breads out there at 15 g a slice. Also Russian Rye and Pumpernickel breads at 15 g a slice.

Katerina, clinical trials take 8 years on average to complete. So two years to complete a phase 1 trial is completely normal. The FDA does not let you test the drug on two or three people and then move on. She needs to prove that this treatment has a positive effect in limited doses over hundreds or thousands of individuals that fit a diverse set of requirements. The study needs to be double-blind and randomized. This takes time and is expensive. 



For an example of why this is expensive, you need only look at her lab equipment. To test if the treatment is having a positive effect on the "bad" t-cells, she built a machine that can sort 1 type of t-cell out of a million other blood cells. This machine costs millions of dollars and a team of engineers to build. And that's merely one small component of completing this project.



To put this in perspective, if she was creating a new drug, it would cost at least $1,000,000,000 - that's one billion dollars - to get to the start of a phase 1 clinical trial. The process to bring a treatment market is expensive and time-consuming no matter how you look at it. 



So I would not look at the minor money involved here (well under $50,000,000) or the short time (less than 24 months to complete a phase 1 trial) and see anything but positive signs. As AlbertE said, most trials never even get to a phase II so this is actually good news all around.

There has been an enormous amount of progress with implanted beta cells protected by immunosuppressant drugs. One approach is encapsulating the cells in a protective layer and then giving localized immunosuppressant drugs right at the site of the transplant. Beta cells also crave oxygen, so there has been engineering work to create chemical reactions that can produce oxygen for 30 days while the beta cells attach to the vascular system. This approach means that you experience no side effects from the drugs (the doses are minuscule compared to taking a full body dose). Other approaches are using stem cells to culture beta cells that don't need immunosuppressants and encapsulating those to save them from the autoimmune response. Both of these approaches are working in animal models and headings towards human trials.



This stuff is miles ahead of where it was 5 years ago.

Katerina, clinical trials take 8 years on average to complete. So two years to complete a phase 1 trial is completely normal. The FDA does not let you test the drug on two or three people and then move on. She needs to prove that this treatment has a positive effect in limited doses over hundreds or thousands of individuals that fit a diverse set of requirements. The study needs to be double-blind and randomized. This takes time and is expensive. 



For an example of why this is expensive, you need only look at her lab equipment. To test if the treatment is having a positive effect on the "bad" t-cells, she built a machine that can sort 1 type of t-cell out of a million other blood cells. This machine costs millions of dollars and a team of engineers to build. And that's merely one small component of completing this project.



To put this in perspective, if she was creating a new drug, it would cost at least $1,000,000,000 - that's one billion dollars - to get to the start of a phase 1 clinical trial. The process to bring a treatment market is expensive and time-consuming no matter how you look at it. 



So I would not look at the minor money involved here (well under $50,000,000) or the short time (less than 24 months to complete a phase 1 trial) and see anything but positive signs. As AlbertE said, most trials never even get to a phase II so this is actually good news all around.

Katerina, clinical trials take 8 years on average to complete. So two years to complete a phase 1 trial is completely normal. The FDA does not let you test the drug on two or three people and then move on. She needs to prove that this treatment has a positive effect in limited doses over hundreds or thousands of individuals that fit a diverse set of requirements. The study needs to be double-blind and randomized. This takes time and is expensive. 



For an example of why this is expensive, you need only look at her lab equipment. To test if the treatment is having a positive effect on the "bad" t-cells, she built a machine that can sort 1 type of t-cell out of a million other blood cells. This machine costs millions of dollars and a team of engineers to build. And that's merely one small component of completing this project.



To put this in perspective, if she was creating a new drug, it would cost at least $1,000,000,000 - that's one billion dollars - to get to the start of a phase 1 clinical trial. The process to bring a treatment market is expensive and time-consuming no matter how you look at it. 



So I would not look at the minor money involved here (well under $50,000,000) or the short time (less than 24 months to complete a phase 1 trial) and see anything but positive signs. As AlbertE said, most trials never even get to a phase II so this is actually good news all around.

question: Sourdough bread may be better than whole wheat
answers: I absolutely love sourdough bread. I don't eat it though. The carb counts on sourdough bread are more than double the carbs per slice of any other bread. I don't eat much bread at all but when I do it's a thin slice of light bread at 8 carbs per slice. Most sourdough bread I've seen around here is 25 carbs per slice. Katerina, clinical trials take 8 years on average to complete. So two years to complete a phase 1 trial is completely normal. The FDA does not let you test the drug on two or three people and then move on. She needs to prove that this treatment has a positive effect in limited doses over hundreds or thousands of individuals that fit a diverse set of requirements. The study needs to be double-blind and randomized. This takes time and is expensive. 



For an example of why this is expensive, you need only look at her lab equipment. To test if the treatment is having a positive effect on the "bad" t-cells, she built a machine that can sort 1 type of t-cell out of a million other blood cells. This machine costs millions of dollars and a team of engineers to build. And that's merely one small component of completing this project.



To put this in perspective, if she was creating a new drug, it would cost at least $1,000,000,000 - that's one billion dollars - to get to the start of a phase 1 clinical trial. The process to bring a treatment market is expensive and time-consuming no matter how you look at it.

There has been an enormous amount of progress with implanted beta cells protected by immunosuppressant drugs. One approach is encapsulating the cells in a protective layer and then giving localized immunosuppressant drugs right at the site of the transplant. Beta cells also crave oxygen, so there has been engineering work to create chemical reactions that can produce oxygen for 30 days while the beta cells attach to the vascular system. This approach means that you experience no side effects from the drugs (the doses are minuscule compared to taking a full body dose). Other approaches are using stem cells to culture beta cells that don't need immunosuppressants and encapsulating those to save them from the autoimmune response. Both of these approaches are working in animal models and headings towards human trials.

question: Sourdough bread may be better than whole wheat
answers: I absolutely love sourdough bread. I don't eat it though. The carb counts on sourdough bread are more than double the carbs per slice of any other bread. I don't eat much bread at all but when I do it's a thin slice of light bread at 8 carbs per slice. Most sourdough bread I've seen around here is 25 carbs per slice. I go through the roof.....Of course I love the stuff...just can't hardly eat it.

There has been an enormous amount of progress with implanted beta cells protected by immunosuppressant drugs. One approach is encapsulating the cells in a protective layer and then giving localized immunosuppressant drugs right at the site of the transplant. Beta cells also crave oxygen, so there has been engineering work to create chemical reactions that can produce oxygen for 30 days while the beta cells attach to the vascular system. This approach means that you experience no side effects from the drugs (the doses are minuscule compared to taking a full body dose). Other approaches are using stem cells to culture beta cells that don't need immunosuppressants and encapsulating those to save them from the autoimmune response. Both of these approaches are working in animal models and headings towards human trials.

question: Sourdough bread may be better than whole wheat
answers: I absolutely love sourdough bread. I don't eat it though. The carb counts on sourdough bread are more than double the carbs per slice of any other bread. I don't eat much bread at all but when I do it's a thin slice of light bread at 8 carbs per slice. Most sourdough bread I've seen around here is 25 carbs per slice. One slice of bread would my whole meals worth of carbs.

For me.....sourdough bread is like taking a piece of white bread and pouring a Coke on it.

I go through the roof.....Of course I love the stuff...just can't hardly eat it.

Certainly everyone is different, but what I found interesting is the finding that the oft-recommended "whole wheat" bread had greater impact and over a longer period of time.  It's not always sufficient to give a passing grade to something that doesn't spike you very much at two hours.
There are sourdough breads out there at 15 g a slice. Also Russian Rye and Pumpernickel breads at 15 g a slice.

But I only eat a couple slices at a time and haven't measure blood sugar diligently. But I do recommend it as long as you make it at home if you crave carbs like I do. It took me five years to lose the sugar craving, and I'm really just starting to work on the carb craving. It seems more difficult since there are always carbs around in one form or another.



PS- you can get 50 lbs of flour for around $15, and sourdough is easy to make, just takes some time.

There has been an enormous amount of progress with implanted beta cells protected by immunosuppressant drugs. One approach is encapsulating the cells in a protective layer and then giving localized immunosuppressant drugs right at the site of the transplant. Beta cells also crave oxygen, so there has been engineering work to create chemical reactions that can produce oxygen for 30 days while the beta cells attach to the vascular system. This approach means that you experience no side effects from the drugs (the doses are minuscule compared to taking a full body dose). Other approaches are using stem cells to culture beta cells that don't need immunosuppressants and encapsulating those to save them from the autoimmune response. Both of these approaches are working in animal models and headings towards human trials.

question: Sourdough bread may be better than whole wheat
answers: I absolutely love sourdough bread. I don't eat it though. The carb counts on sourdough bread are more than double the carbs per slice of any other bread. I don't eat much bread at all but when I do it's a thin slice of light bread at 8 carbs per slice. Most sourdough bread I've seen around here is 25 carbs per slice. One slice of bread would my whole meals worth of carbs.

For me.....sourdough bread is like taking a piece of white bread and pouring a Coke on it.

I go through the roof.....Of course I love the stuff...just can't hardly eat it.

Certainly everyone is different, but what I found interesting is the finding that the oft-recommended "whole wheat" bread had greater impact and over a longer period of time.  It's not always sufficient to give a passing grade to something that doesn't spike you very much at two hours.

Katerina, clinical trials take 8 years on average to complete. So two years to complete a phase 1 trial is completely normal. The FDA does not let you test the drug on two or three people and then move on. She needs to prove that this treatment has a positive effect in limited doses over hundreds or thousands of individuals that fit a diverse set of requirements. The study needs to be double-blind and randomized. This takes time and is expensive. 



For an example of why this is expensive, you need only look at her lab equipment. To test if the treatment is having a positive effect on the "bad" t-cells, she built a machine that can sort 1 type of t-cell out of a million other blood cells. This machine costs millions of dollars and a team of engineers to build. And that's merely one small component of completing this project.



To put this in perspective, if she was creating a new drug, it would cost at least $1,000,000,000 - that's one billion dollars - to get to the start of a phase 1 clinical trial. The process to bring a treatment market is expensive and time-consuming no matter how you look at it. 



So I would not look at the minor money involved here (well under $50,000,000) or the short time (less than 24 months to complete a phase 1 trial) and see anything but positive signs. As AlbertE said, most trials never even get to a phase II so this is actually good news all around.

She needs to prove that this treatment has a positive effect in limited doses over hundreds or thousands of individuals that fit a diverse set of requirements. The study needs to be double-blind and randomized. This takes time and is expensive. 



For an example of why this is expensive, you need only look at her lab equipment. To test if the treatment is having a positive effect on the "bad" t-cells, she built a machine that can sort 1 type of t-cell out of a million other blood cells. This machine costs millions of dollars and a team of engineers to build. And that's merely one small component of completing this project.



To put this in perspective, if she was creating a new drug, it would cost at least $1,000,000,000 - that's one billion dollars - to get to the start of a phase 1 clinical trial. The process to bring a treatment market is expensive and time-consuming no matter how you look at it. 



So I would not look at the minor money involved here (well under $50,000,000) or the short time (less than 24 months to complete a phase 1 trial) and see anything but positive signs. As AlbertE said, most trials never even get to a phase II so this is actually good news all around.

question: Sourdough bread may be better than whole wheat
answers: I absolutely love sourdough bread. I don't eat it though. The carb counts on sourdough bread are more than double the carbs per slice of any other bread. There has been an enormous amount of progress with implanted beta cells protected by immunosuppressant drugs. One approach is encapsulating the cells in a protective layer and then giving localized immunosuppressant drugs right at the site of the transplant. Beta cells also crave oxygen, so there has been engineering work to create chemical reactions that can produce oxygen for 30 days while the beta cells attach to the vascular system. This approach means that you experience no side effects from the drugs (the doses are minuscule compared to taking a full body dose). Other approaches are using stem cells to culture beta cells that don't need immunosuppressants and encapsulating those to save them from the autoimmune response. Both of these approaches are working in animal models and headings towards human trials.

There has been an enormous amount of progress with implanted beta cells protected by immunosuppressant drugs. One approach is encapsulating the cells in a protective layer and then giving localized immunosuppressant drugs right at the site of the transplant. Beta cells also crave oxygen, so there has been engineering work to create chemical reactions that can produce oxygen for 30 days while the beta cells attach to the vascular system. This approach means that you experience no side effects from the drugs (the doses are minuscule compared to taking a full body dose). Other approaches are using stem cells to culture beta cells that don't need immunosuppressants and encapsulating those to save them from the autoimmune response. Both of these approaches are working in animal models and headings towards human trials.

question: Sourdough bread may be better than whole wheat
answers: I absolutely love sourdough bread. I don't eat it though. The carb counts on sourdough bread are more than double the carbs per slice of any other bread. I don't eat much bread at all but when I do it's a thin slice of light bread at 8 carbs per slice. Most sourdough bread I've seen around here is 25 carbs per slice. One slice of bread would my whole meals worth of carbs.

For me.....sourdough bread is like taking a piece of white bread and pouring a Coke on it.

I go through the roof.....Of course I love the stuff...just can't hardly eat it.

Certainly everyone is different, but what I found interesting is the finding that the oft-recommended "whole wheat" bread had greater impact and over a longer period of time.  It's not always sufficient to give a passing grade to something that doesn't spike you very much at two hours.

There has been an enormous amount of progress with implanted beta cells protected by immunosuppressant drugs. One approach is encapsulating the cells in a protective layer and then giving localized immunosuppressant drugs right at the site of the transplant. Beta cells also crave oxygen, so there has been engineering work to create chemical reactions that can produce oxygen for 30 days while the beta cells attach to the vascular system.
